data.meta_description: Congratulations to our eTown General Manager, Marcy Pollicino for being honored with the prestigious Laurel Award for "Lifestyle Director of the Year" by the…
data.text:
As we don our emerald hues to celebrate Saint Patrick’s Day, it is a moment not just of cultural celebration but of profound reflection on the tapestry that weaves our professional and personal lives into a vibrant quilt of diversity and innovation. Saint Patrick’s Day transcends its geographical origins, morphing into a global festivity that symbolizes more than just national pride; it represents the resilience, creativity, and collaborative spirit inherent in our global professional community. It’s a day that encourages us to look beyond the superficial and delve into the rich layers of multicultural heritage that shape our corporate landscapes. This occasion serves as a poignant reminder of the strength found in unity and diversity. As professionals, it beckons us to embrace the varied backgrounds and perspectives that enrich our workplaces, fuel innovation, and drive us toward common goals. The symbiotic relationship between diverse thought processes and innovative solutions is akin to the intricate patterns of a Celtic knot, seamlessly interwoven and infinitely complex. Moreover, Saint Patrick’s Day prompts us to reflect on our journey, acknowledge our achievements, and set our sights on future aspirations. It’s a time to celebrate the professional milestones achieved through hard work, perseverance, and the invaluable support of our colleagues and mentors. As we commemorate this day, let us renew our commitment to fostering an inclusive, equitable, and innovative work environment. Let us continue to champion the ideals of collaboration, respect, and mutual growth. In the spirit of Saint Patrick, may we strive to be leaders who not only envision change but also act as catalysts for positive transformation within our industries and communities. Happy Saint Patrick’s Day to all. May the day bring inspiration, unity, and renewed energy as we continue to navigate the complexities of our professional endeavors. #SaintPatricksDay2024 #Leadership #DiversityAndInclusion #Innovation #ProfessionalGrowth #GlobalUnity #CulturalCelebration #Teamwork #BusinessSuccess #SustainableBusiness #Networking #CorporateCulture #Empowerment #ProfessionalDevelopment #CulturalHeritage #InclusiveLeadership #GreenInitiative #IndustryInnovation #CollaborativeCulture #StrategicThinking #CommunityBuilding

Ever heard of St. Andrew's Day? It's celebrated by Scottish people and their descendants around the world on November 30. It isn't an official holiday here in Canada, but there are plenty of celebrations involving eating, drinking and dancing! It may sound odd, but tradition is an important part of change. Too often, we are so focused on the future that we neglect to remember and honour the traditions and practices that can help support us during times of change. For me, remembering and celebrating St. Andrew's Day helps me connect with my ancestors and heritage. If you're leading change on a project, remember to ask your stakeholders questions about team traditions or festivities. Incorporating well-known practices can help ground and support a team that's going through change. If you're planning change in your personal or professional life, consider what traditions are important to you. Traditions don't have to be big, or well-known to make an impact. Do you have traditions or practices that help ground you during times of change? Let me know in the comments! #ChangeWithoutPain #ChangeManagement #Leadership #ProfessionalDevelopment #HappyStAndrewsDay2023

I'm trading boardrooms for barns and skyscrapers for Ferris wheels for the down-to-earth charm of the Norfolk County Fair in Simcoe, Canada. This isn't just any fair—it's a family legacy, a community cornerstone, and a celebration of all things Canadian. My family has been involved in this fair almost as long as its inception in 1840! That's 27 years before Canada even became a country. My late grandfather, Lloyd Sylvenus Culver, was the fair manager from 1937 to 1973. Under his watch, the fair saw its most significant growth, including the construction of multiple buildings that still stand today. My late father, Syl, was the general manager for over 30 years. Today, my brother Aaron continues the tradition in a leadership role as the facilities manager, continuing a tradition that's been in our family for generations. This week-long extravaganza attracts over 115,000 visitors annually and features everything from equine shows to giant pumpkins. It's not just a fair; it's a million-dollar business that showcases the best in new technology, productivity, and efficiency practices, bridging the gap between urban and rural communities. This fair is my North Star. It's where I've built friendships since I was eight months old, won first prize for my bread and butter pickles, and even survived every single ride on the Midway (though I wouldn't recommend that last one unless you have a strong stomach!). In a constantly changing world, it's essential to have a constant—a touchstone that keeps you grounded and reminds you of your core values. That's what the Norfolk County Fair does for me, and that's what I bring into my leadership style: authenticity, resilience, and a deep-rooted sense of community. #Canada #Leadership #Community #StrategicResilience #TheCulverGroupInc #NorfolkFair
